In contrast to cells and bacteria, which can be cultivated on Petri dishes, viruses cannot be grown on such media. The invention of alternative forms of microbiological culturing allowed microbes to be studied beyond the realm of disease. The Winogradsky column, developed by Sergej Winogradsky in the 1880s, introduced microorganisms as environmental, ecological forces that are capable of producing carbon dioxide and nitrogen, two elements necessary to life.
